column1: Piece of the Berlin Wall at Cafe Turko
column5: Just up the street from the J.P. Patches statue and right around the corner from theFremont Trollis a quaint Turkish cafe featuring a nondescript little chunk of concrete that was once a piece of the Iron Curtain.This concrete is actually a rare segment of the Berlin Wall. Standing at 6 feet by 12 feet, it is relatively minute compared toother preserved sections of the wall. Yet its presence invokes the same visions of poverty and despair that afflicted Germany during the Cold War.However, this piece of the Wall that stands in front of Cafe Turko is now just a part of the surrounding neighborhood. The waitstaff are nonchalant about their historic bauble, explaining that it came to them when the local “History House” museum closed up shop, offering the potentially priceless chunk of rebar and concrete to the restaurant simply for lack of a better alternative.
column6: A nondescript Seattle restaurant inherited a piece of European history.
